misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Implemented distance calculation instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a full solution for computing the distance between two points rather than a program that reads a single numeric grade (0–100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade using conditional ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: This program is an acceptable solution for the grade calculator question, or solving any programming question with a working Java program is sufficient even if it doesn’t match the specified behavior.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must directly implement the given specification: read one numeric grade from 0 to 100, use conditional ranges (if/else) to determine whether it is A, B, C, D, or F, and print the corresponding letter grade. Code that solves a different problem, even if correct for that problem, does not satisfy the requirements.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade.
No conditional logic (if/else) is used to map numeric ranges to letter grades.
Program computes differences, squares, and a square root (distance formula) rather than checking grade intervals.
Output message reports a distance between two points instead of a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between assignment problems or reuse of a previous template without adapting it to the grade calculator specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard the distance-formula logic and start from the problem statement: read one double or int for the grade, then use an if/else-if chain to test 90–100, 80–89, 70–79, 60–69, and below 60, printing the appropriate letter grade. Double-check that prompts and output text match the required behavior.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program is dedicated to computing a geometric distance; there is no reference to grades, ranges, letters, or conditionals, so it clearly does not implement the required grade calculator.

evidence.snippet:
public class DistanceBetweenPoints {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
evidence.note: Class and main method are named and documented for a distance-between-points problem, not a grade calculator.
Program reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single numeric grade, showing a mismatch with the required input behavior.
Core logic computes a Euclidean distance and prints it, with no conditional checks for grade ranges and no letter grade output.

misconceptions.name: Submitted Code for Wrong Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points (a likely solution to a different problem) instead of the required Grade Calculator problem. The code does not contain any logic for reading a single numeric grade or for using conditional statements to assign a corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that the submitted file (DistanceBetweenPoints.java) fulfills the requirements for Question 3 (Grade Calculator), or they mistakenly uploaded an irrelevant file.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Question 3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and implementing if-else if logic to output a discrete letter grade (A, B, C, D, F). The distance formula is not required.
symptoms: Code prompts for and reads four coordinate inputs (x1, y1, x2, y2).
Code calculates the Euclidean distance using the distance formula.
Code outputs the calculated distance instead of a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to verify the submitted code against the current problem statement or organizational error resulting in the submission of an incorrect file.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the requirements for Question 3 and implement the correct logic using conditional statements (if/else if) to map a single input grade to a letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code's entire functionality (variable names, inputs, calculations, and output statement) unambiguously addresses the 'Distance Between Points' problem, proving a critical divergence from the 'Grade Calculator' prompt.

evidence.note: The class name indicates the code solves the wrong problem.
Variables are declared for coordinate geometry, not for processing a grade.
The input reads four coordinates instead of one numeric grade.
The computation and output are for distance, not a letter grade classification.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submitted
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for calculating the distance between two points instead of implementing a grade calculator. This is a fundamental task comprehension failure where the student either submitted the wrong file or copy-pasted code from a different assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either misread the assignment requirements or accidentally submitted code from a different problem (distance calculation between two points).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional logic with Boolean ranges to output the corresponding letter grade (A: 90-100, B: 80-89, C: 70-79, D: 60-69, F: <60).
symptoms: Code reads four coordinate values (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of one grade
Code calculates Euclidean distance instead of mapping grades to letters
Output is a numeric distance, not a letter grade
Class is named 'DistanceBetweenPoints' instead of something related to grade calculation
No conditional logic (if-else) for grade range checking exists
No letter grade output mechanism is present
misconceptions.root_cause: Task comprehension failure—either the student submitted the wrong file, copy-pasted code from a previous assignment, or did not read the problem specification carefully.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over with the grade calculator. Read one grade value from input, then use nested if-else statements to check: if (grade >= 90) then 'A', else if (grade >= 80) then 'B', and so on. Output the letter grade in the format 'Letter grade: X'.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (Euclidean distance) with different input, processing, and output. This is not a minor logical error but a fundamental mismatch to the assignment.

evidence.note: Class name and input reading demonstrate student is solving distance calculation, not grade calculator problem.
Euclidean distance formula implementation confirms wrong problem. Grade calculator should use if-else conditionals, not arithmetic.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Output is a numeric distance value, not a letter grade. Does not match required output format 'Letter grade: X'.

misconceptions.name: Implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a complete program to compute the distance between two points in 2D space rather than a program that reads a single numeric grade (0–100) and outputs the corresponding letter grade (A–F). The code never reads a single grade value, never checks grade ranges, and never outputs a letter grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to read two coordinate points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2), compute the distance between them using the distance formula, and print that distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program should read exactly one numeric grade between 0 and 100 from the user, then use conditional statements to determine which letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) corresponds to that numeric value, and finally print the appropriate letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates ("Enter x1 and y1", "Enter x2 and y2") instead of a grade
Program reads four double values instead of one numeric grade
Program computes a Euclidean distance using Math.sqrt instead of checking grade ranges
Program prints "The distance of the two points is ..." instead of a letter grade such as A, B, C, D, or F
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment questions or reuse of a previous solution without adapting it to the current problem specification. The student focused on implementing the distance formula rather than carefully aligning their program with the requested grade-calculator behavior.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and redesign the program around it: declare a single variable to store a numeric grade (0–100), read that one value from the user, then use if/else-if/else statements to check which range it falls into (90–100, 80–89, etc.) and print the corresponding letter grade.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to program structure
Using Scanner to read a single numeric value
Using conditionals to implement range checks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is structured around distance computation with no trace of grade-related logic, which consistently contradicts the given problem specification.

evidence.note: All core logic is dedicated to reading two points and computing their distance instead of reading a single grade and mapping it to a letter grade.

Program calculates Euclidean distance.
No use of extensive conditional logic (if/else if) is present.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to submit the correct file for the assignment question (Q3).

misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code provided is undeniably solving a distance calculation problem, proven by variable names, mathematical operations (subtraction, squaring, square root), and output message. It does not contain any logic related to the Grade Calculator problem described in Q3.
